title: Tudor mansion with Kate Middleton and Prince William as neighbours on the market
text:
1
View
comments
A stunning Grade I Tudor mansion in Norfolk may be turned into a hotel, unless the current owner can find a buyer to pay the whopping £3.95m asking price.
Wolterton Manor House, in East Barsham, Norfolk, appears to be straight out of a fairy tale - complete with royal neighbours, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, at the nearby Anmer Hall.
The stately brick home includes a Great Hall and seven bedrooms over four and a half acres.
A stunning Grade I Tudor property in Norfolk may be turned into a hotel, unless a buyer can be found
With similar features to Henry VIII's palace at Hampton Court, Wolterton Manor House is rumoured to have also played host to the King.
According to local lore, Henry also walked barefoot from the house to the shrine at Walsingham Priory to pay for a son and heir.

First built for Sir Henry Fermor, it's been privately owned for centuries - mostly by aristocratic families - before being purchased by pop artist and businessman, Roy Griffiths, last year.
Griffiths had initially planned to turn the property into a boutique hotel, though objecting neighbours ultimately stalled his plans.
The stunning home boasts many similar features to Henry VIII's palace at Hampton Court
Wolterton Manor House has not undergone extensive renovations, but is on the market for £3.95million
The stately brick home includes a Great Hall and seven bedrooms over 4 and a half acres
The multi-million pound property also comes with some well-known neighbours - the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge live at the nearby Anmer Hall
With running costs of up to £2,000 per week, Griffiths has now put the house on the market, unwilling to deal with the sky-high maintenance fees.
As it stands, the only person who lives in the house is the gardener - Griffiths lives in a cottage connected to the triple garage.
He does use the home, however, having turned the drawing room into a modern art studio.
The Great Room is another particularly impressive feature, measuring 41 feet long and boasting a large stone fireplace.
The home, with its brick gate, looks like it could be straight out of a fairy tale
Roy Griffiths, a pop artist, purchased the house a year ago and turned one of the rooms into an art studio
The home was initially built for Sir Henry Fermor and has been privately owned - mostly by aristocratic families ever since
Unfortunately, with running costs of up to £2,000 per week, Griffiths has now put the house on the market
The owner is torn over whether he wants to sell the home to a family or to someone willing to turn it into a hotel
It had initially been Griffiths dream to turn the property into a boutique hotel, though objecting neighbours stalled his plans
A grand staircase is another noteworthy feature of the property - despite the fact that the only person who lives in the house is the gardener
If the property doesn't sell in six months, Griffiths hopes to go ahead with plans
Griffiths purchased the house in 2014 for £2.75m, though has upped the price almost 50 per cent for incoming buyers.
'They tell me to sell the house and spend the money,' Griffiths tells The Sunday Times of his family's support for his decision.
And while Griffiths believes that children would love the home and hopes to sell it to a family, another part of him would love to see his original boutique hotel dream come to life.
Though the price tag may seem lofty, experts believe that it should still sell given today's market.
'The price difference reflects the change in market confidence over the past year,' William von Siegmund, head of Sotheby's country office tells the weekend newspaper.
If, in six months, the property still has not gone, Griffiths plans to put in the application to develop the property into a hotel anyway.
